Mike Woodhouse wrote:

> Emyr,
>
>I have a few (!) thoughts on this, based partly on my own fiddlings
>and partly on a lot of reading on the subject in the past. [deep
>breath] Here goes...
>
>* Consider using daily returns not prices, i.e. percentage price
>change up/down. It saves your network having to strip out the boring
>part of the price...
>
>* Confidence sounds like a smart place to be - in particular when two
>similar input vectors might result in wildly different outcomes (a
>major problem with backprop) - the network can simlpy say "dunno"
>  
>
Yeh I agree that this is a *really* important thing to implement. In 
fact it would be fine if a network just said 'dunno' 99% of the time so 
long as it is corect most of the time when it gives a positive signal.

>* Fitness function: profit? return on capital invested? volatility?
>Sharpe Ratio? Be sure to factor in trading costs (execution fees,
>stamp duties, margin/funding costs if using CFDs) as they can kill
>models that evolve to "scalp" (sell on an uptick), which some of the
>big boys can afford to do because of the cheapness of individual
>transactions compared to the rest of us.
>  
>
As I said in an ealrier email, I would prefer to take as much work out 
of the network as possible. E.g. instead of getting buy/sell signals I 
would prefer the network to give me price (or price change) predictions 
and I can then write some simple business logic that can determine if  
this information can be used to make a profit. If I can do this part in 
code then why would I try an evolve a network to do it? Keep the 
network's job as simple as possible.

>* Outputs - consider something like 
>-1.0 .. -0.8	open short position
>-0.8 .. -0.5	stay short
>-0.5 .. -0.3	cover short
>-0.3 .. +0.3	nothing to do
>+0.3 .. +0.5	close long
>+0.5 .. +0.8	stay long
>+0.8 .. +1.0	open long position
>  
>
Ah, so the network can indicate not only a price at a given point in the 
future, but actually indicate a varying point in the future. Whereas 
with my approach (with the seperate business logic) we would need the 
network to output a price estimation for a range of points in the future 
- actually this is the same thing huh. So yeh, I'd go along with this 
approach.

>* Go Short? Well, you can if you trade with CFDs (Contracts For
>Difference) rather than actual shares. IIRC correctly, you can go long
>without paying Stamp Duty as well...
>  
>
Here's were your market knowledge clearly exceeds my own! Spread betting 
gives you similar abilities, right? Without the need to pay 
broker/transaction charges.

>* Efficient Market Hypothesis says all available information is in the
>price. Well, it may get there eventually but I don't believe it's
>instantaneous! Therefore it could be useful to provide information
>outside of the stock price. Some possibilities:
>- Days (or fraction of the normal period) since (or to) announcements
>of results
>  
>
I like this idea. e.g. a price rise may be due to an imminent mildy 
positive announcement or a very positive announcement still some 
distance in the future. I don't think you can determine which case is in 
effect in advance with just the price alone.

There is a whole bunch of stuff you could apply to the networks and you 
can never supply all of the available information, therefore I think I 
prefer to go for a conservative approach and just stick to the basics. 
If there are outside (as far as the network is concerned) factors at 
play then the network can just set it 'dunno' output high.  Think about 
it like this, the network can either be very good as predicting one or 
two specific events, or it can be less good at predicting a whole range 
of events. If we keep the input/output space lean then the searches will 
(theoritically) have more chance at success - assuming they have enough 
info to make a prediction of course. Swings and roundabouts huh.

>
>* Oh, Dividends. Remember that share prices fall by the dividend
>amount on the ex-div date (or by approximately the present value
>thereof but near as dammit). So you'll either need to factor dividends
>back into the price (not recommended, they're a realised one, whereas
>in the price they're unrealised and rather less liquid) or (a) add the
>dividend amount to your P&L
>
P&L?

> and tell your network that the price drop
>is OK, either by flagging the data on the date on an extra input or
>more pragmatically just dropping the day from your input data set.
>  
>
But there may be profit opportunities here, if, say there are certain 
subtle situations where the market as a whole may temporarily re-adjust 
to the div payment incorrectly - e.g. if there were other complicating 
factors effecting the price at the same time. I prefer letting the 
network know what the dividend payment will be and when it will be paid, 
is that possible?

>I believe that there are companies using AI techniques in the markets,
>D E Shaw is one that comes to mind, and there are/were a group in what
>is now part of UBS (was Swiss Bank, was O'Brien(?)) that were in Santa
>Fe, as described in The Predictors
>  
>
Have you read it? Are these guys for real? and if so why did they go to 
the effort of writing a book? :)
